title: 109_hr3558
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Amendments Act of 2005". Congress finds that the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project, a major component of the Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program, flooded the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation, causing significant economic and cultural damage to the tribe. Compensation has been provided to affected tribes, including the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act (Public Law 106-511; 114 Stat. 2365) created the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund to compensate members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Act aims to provide additional compensation and capitalize the Trust Fund. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act created a Trust Fund to compensate members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to ensure fair compensation for land acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservation project. The definitions section of the Act is also revised for clarity. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to define terms like "member landowner" and "power program." The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund receives funding from the power program for fair compensation. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act defines terms like "member landowner" and "power program." Funding for fair compensation is received from the power program based on a specific amount calculated annually. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act defines terms like "member landowner" and "power program." The Act allows for additional compensation to member landowners for land acquisition by the United States for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Tribal Council, determines the Bond Index or a similar index. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act allows for additional compensation to member landowners for land acquisition by the United States for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Secretary of the Interior must provide requested records to the Tribe to identify heirs of member landowners within 60 days. The Act is amended to include eligibility of member landowners for certain programs and services.
